title: How to Make Bread and Apricot Pudding

steps.headline: Fill a pudding dish with alternate layers of breadcrumbs and canned apricots.
Make the custard using the ingredients specified above.
Pour the custard over the layers of fruit and breadcrumbs.
Place in a moderate oven.
steps.description: Bake for a half hour or until the custard sets.

steps.headline: Serve.
steps.description: This goes well with whipped cream or butterscotch sauce.

steps.headline: Prepare the ingredients:
steps.description: Chop the chocolate coarsely, into small pieces. Cut the dried apricots into quarters. Trim the crusts off the bread. Then cut into ⁄4 inch (1.9 cm)-thick slices, crosswise.

steps.headline: Place the bread slices in a buttered square pan.
steps.description: It is appropriate to overlap the slices, just don't let them extend above the pan sides.

steps.headline: Place the chopped chocolate and dried apricots in the pan.
steps.description: Push the pieces in between the slices of bread you've already arranged. With what is remaining, sprinkle across the top of the bread slices.

steps.headline: Crack the eggs into a mixing bowl.
steps.description: Add the half and half, vanilla extract and orange liqueur or orange juice. Whisk everything together and blend well.

steps.headline: Pour the egg mixture over the bread slices.
steps.description: Do this carefully and slowly, covering the entire dish evenly. Let the egg mixture stand until the bread almost completely absorbs it; this will take around half an hour to 40 minutes. You can help the soaking process by spooning the liquid over the bread now and then.

steps.headline: Heat the oven to 350ºF/180ºC.
steps.description: Bake the pudding for about 30 minutes or until the custard no longer flows when the pan is tilted. Be sure to wear oven mitts before tilting the pan to check.

steps.headline: Remove from the oven.
steps.description: If you want a golden hue to the top, broil or top-down grill the top for just a few minutes.

steps.headline: Serve.
steps.description: The pudding can be served warm from the oven or cold. Serve with whipped cream or ice cream.

text: Bread and apricot pudding Fill a pudding dish with alternate layers of breadcrumbs and canned apricots.  Make the custard using the ingredients specified above.  Pour the custard over the layers of fruit and breadcrumbs.  Place in a moderate oven. Bake for a half hour or until the custard sets. Serve. This goes well with whipped cream or butterscotch sauce. Bread, apricot and chocolate pudding Prepare the ingredients: Chop the chocolate coarsely, into small pieces. Cut the dried apricots into quarters. Trim the crusts off the bread. Then cut into ⁄4 inch (1.9 cm)-thick slices, crosswise. Place the bread slices in a buttered square pan. It is appropriate to overlap the slices, just don't let them extend above the pan sides. Place the chopped chocolate and dried apricots in the pan. Push the pieces in between the slices of bread you've already arranged. With what is remaining, sprinkle across the top of the bread slices. Crack the eggs into a mixing bowl. Add the half and half, vanilla extract and orange liqueur or orange juice. Whisk everything together and blend well. Pour the egg mixture over the bread slices. Do this carefully and slowly, covering the entire dish evenly. Let the egg mixture stand until the bread almost completely absorbs it; this will take around half an hour to 40 minutes. You can help the soaking process by spooning the liquid over the bread now and then. Heat the oven to 350ºF/180ºC. Bake the pudding for about 30 minutes or until the custard no longer flows when the pan is tilted. Be sure to wear oven mitts before tilting the pan to check. Remove from the oven. If you want a golden hue to the top, broil or top-down grill the top for just a few minutes. Serve. The pudding can be served warm from the oven or cold. Serve with whipped cream or ice cream. Finished.
